questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Rosacea is characterized by a persistent erythema of the convex surfaces of the face, with the cheeks and nose most frequently affected, followed by involvement of the brow and chin. There is a tendency to spare the periocular skin. Rosacea occurs most often in light skinned women between the ages of 30 and 50; however, the severe type with phymatous changes occurs almost exclusively in men. Additional features commonly manifested include telangiectasia, fl fl ushing, erythematous papules and pustules. Photosensitivity is common. Comedones are never seen

questions.text: Causative factor of acne includes all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Acne vulgaris is exclusively a follicular disease, with the principle abnormality being comedo formation. It is produced by the impaction and distension of the follicles with a keratinous plug in the lower infundibulum. Androgens, alterations in lipid composition, and an abnormal response to local cytokines, Insulin growth factor-1 are all hypothesized to be important. Androgen stimulation of the sebaceous glands is critical. Acne begins after sebum secretion increases and women with hyperandrogenic states often manifest acne, along with hirsutism and menstrual abnormalities. As the retained cells block the follicular opening, the lower ortion of the follicle is dilated by entrapped sebum. Disruption of the follicular epithelium permits discharge of the follicular contents into the dermis. The combination of keratin, sebum, and microorganisms, particularly Propionibacterium acnes, leads to the release of proinfl ammatory mediators and inflammation

questions.text: A teenage girl with moderate acne also has irregular menses. Drug of choice would be
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The question points to a diagnosis of hormonal acne due to PCOD. Cyproterone acetate is an anti-androgen useful here. The diagnosis is hormonal acne due to PCOD. Best drug will be oral contraceptive pill

Correct Answer (D) It is a slow growing tumor due to hypertrophy of sebaceous glands of tip of nose. Rhinophyma (an advanced type of rosacea) is characterized by an enlarged, bulbous, and red nose resulting from enlargement of the oil-producing glands beneath the surface of the skin on the nose. Often seen in long standing cases of Acne Rosacea. Rosacea is a chronic disease that affects the skin. The disease is characterized by redness, pimples, and, in advanced stages, thickened skin. When rosacea reaches this advanced stage, rhinophyma may develop. Bulb-like shape of nose Many oil glands, reddish color Thickening of the skin

questions.text: In Fox Fordyce disease, true is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Fox-fordyce disease is characterized by conical, fl fl esh-colored or grayish, intensely pruritic, discrete follicular papules in areas where apocrine glands occur. The axillae and areolae are the primary sites of involvement. Bullous lesions are not seen. It is not related to sebum. No form of therapy is universally effective for Fox–Fordyce disease. Oral contraceptive pills, topical tretinoin or adapalene, topical tacrolimus or corticosteroid creams, intralesional steroids, topical clindamycin solution, benzoyl peroxide, isotretinoin, and UV phototherapy have all been effective in small numbers of patients.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 2-year-old h/o erythematous papulopustular lesions of convexities of the face. There in a background of erythema & telangiectasia. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Erythematous papulopustular lesions of convexities of the face and background of erythema &telangiectasia suggests rosacea. SLE will have erythema but not the other features. Acne will have papules and pustules but not the other features. Polymorphous light eruptions will have itchy and photosensitivity
Correct Answer (D) Acne is treated with benzoyl peroxide, oral Isotretinoin, adapalene. Testosterone would increase acne due to androgen stimulation of sebum glands.

questions.text: Treatment of nodulocystic acne on face is
questions.solution: C. Isotretinoin Oral Isotretinoin is approved only for severesevere Nodulocystic acne: however, it is useful in less severe forms of acne. Additionally, other agreed indications were in?ammatory rosacea, and hidradenitis suppurativa. The dose is 0.5–1 mg/kg/ day in one or two daily doses. To obtain the greatest chance of a prolonged remission, patients should receive 120–150 mg/kg over the treatment course.

questions.text: Crystalline miliaria is due to obstruction to
questions.solution: B. Sweat ducts Miliaria, the retention of sweat as a result of occlusion of eccrine sweat ducts, produces an eruption that is common in hot, humid climates, such as in the tropics and during the hot summer months in temperate climates. Staphylococcus epidermidis, which produces an extracellular polysaccharide substance, induces miliaria in an experimental setting. This polysaccharide substance may obstruct the delivery of sweat to the skin surface. The occlusion prevents normal secretion from the sweat glands, and eventually pressure causes rupture of the sweat gland or duct at different levels. The escape of sweat into the adjacent tissue produces miliaria. Depending on the level of the injury to the sweat gland or duct, several different forms are recognized. Miliaria crystallina is characterized by small, clear, superficial vesicles with no in?ammatory reaction. It appears in bedridden patients in whom fever produces increased perspiration or in situations in which clothing prevents dissipation of heat and moisture, as in bundled children. The lesions are generally asymptomatic and their duration is shortlived because they tend to rupture at the slightest trauma.

questions.text: A 17 year old with acne has been taking a drug for last two years. She now has blue-black pigmentation of nails. The likely medication causing this would be
questions.solution: B. Minocycline Pigmentation is a well recognised adverse effect of minocycline therapy. Various body sites, most notably the skin, nails, bones, thyroid, mouth and eyes are affected and the pigmentation may appear at multiple sites. In general, pigmentation results from long term administration of minocycline at cumulative doses greater than 100 g, although cutaneous or oral mucosal pigmentation may appear, regardless of dose or duration of therapy. When the skin is involved, the blue-black pigmentation develops most frequently on the shins, ankles and arms. Other patterns of skin involvement include pigmentation that is either generalised and symmetrical, or that develops at sites of inflammation.

choices.text: Chronic discharging sinuses in apocrine areas

questions.text: Following is true for Hidradenitis suppurativa, EXCEPT:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Apocrine miliaria is Fox-Fordyce disease. Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS), also known as acne inversa, is a long-term skin disease characterized by the occurrence of inflamed and swollen lumps. These are typically painful and break open, releasing fluid or pus. The areas most commonly affected are the underarms, under the breasts, and groin. Scar tissue remains after healing. The exact cause is usually unclear but believed to involve a combination of genetic and environmental factors. About a third of people with the disease have an affected family member. Other risk factors include obesity and smoking. The condition is not infectious, related to hygiene, or the use of deodorant. The underlying mechanism is believed to involve either a dysfunction of apocrine sweat glands or hair follicles. Diagnosis is based on the symptoms.

Correct Answer (A) Grading of acne vulgaris: Grade 1 : Comedones predominant. Open Comedones - Black in colour, Atmospheric air comes inside the hair follicle and oxidises the sebum. So they are black in colour. Closed comedones - white in colour Grade 2 : Papules predominant Grade 3 : Pustules predominant Grade 4 : Nodulocystic Acne ( Most severe type)

questions.text: Patient is on treatment with 13-cis retinoic acid. Which of the following is one of the side effect of the drug?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Isotretinoin also known as 13-cis retinoic acid is used in acne.The side effects are:- 1. Dryness 2. Altered LFT and TAG levels 3. Pseudotumor cerebri 4. DISH (diffuse idiopathic skeleton hyperostosis) and teratogenicity like microtia/anotia. Hence,isotretinoin is avoided in pregnancy due to risk of teratogenicity.

questions.text: A female patient presented with acne that is not resolving on oral isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy. Which of the following is the next best investigation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A,C,D-dietary triggers,antibiotic resistance and drug triggers are other factors that may result in non-responsiveness. Option B-The next best step for a female patient with acne that is resistant to oral isotretinoin is to check for hyperandrogenism. Hyperandrogenism usually manifests as hirsutism, acne, and/or androgenetic alopecia. Acne that is persistent, moderate to severe, or late onset raises concern for PCOS or other causes of hyperandrogenism.
